bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Henry Hanson, August 4, 1921

div1.p: Carter, preparing a paper, asks Hanson about his experience in Peru. He believes that Hanson and his team have saved Peru. Carter wishes he could have returned to Peru.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Henry Hanson, August 4, 1921
div1.opener:
I H. B.
Hanson
Adj. to chashal
New Glasgow P. O.,
Amherst County, Va.
August 4, 1921
Dear Hanson:
div1.p:
I am asked for a paper before the American Society of Tropical
Medicine on the Yellow Fever Epidemic in Northern Peru.

Naturally, it would be better written next year and by you and
myself jointly. However, I am purposing to twll what I can of the epidem-
iology and control of this fever for 1920 and want to add a very
brief sketch of the same for /21. I earnestly hope that there will be
none in /22 of which to write.
Will you then kindly give me a few points:
1/ Fish.
Did you use fish for the wells (in the houses) at Casa Grande?

If not, what did you use for these wells? In what other places and
for what class of containers did you use fish? What were your results?
What kind of fish and how obtained? Were they viviparous or oviparous?

How did you find the fever spread at the haciendas? You told me
that the medico at Casa Grande would not admit its diagnos. Did he do so
later? How did it do in haciendas like Roma where there was little
breeding: At Cayati--with inefficient medico--and at Saman?
2/ Limit of Number of Containers.

Were you able generally to limit the number of containers to a
family? We had planned to allow only 2 botijas to each residence - one full & one empty & drying. I
know that Dr. Tapia (your last letter) had ordered, and I presume your
men carried this out, that no large containers be allowed in the sepa-
rate apartments of the large lodging houses.
3/ Emptying Containers without Examination.

Were you able to use the control we had planned--emptying the con-
tainers--preferably alternate containers--every week (or 10) days) without
inspecting it, to see if it had larvae or no?
4/ Where Used.

Where were the above used and by what Inspectors and what were the
results?
5/ Methods.

Anything else you can tell me of your methods of control of ste-
gomyia production is desired--especially as they were the same as, or
differed from, those in use last year.
6/ Origen.

I judge from the outbreak in Olmos and other places in that valley
above Ferrenafe that the fever probably did not enter by way of Morropon:
Salitral and Olmos? Yet it might have done so and died out in the cool
weather to spread in epidemic form when reintroduced in hot weather --
as apparently was the case with Paita in the fall of /19 and summer of
/20. Still this is unlikely as Paita is much colder in the winter than is
the interior. It may not have didn't died out in P. in the cool weather - simply
lessened very much & the s cases occurring at long intervals failed
of report.
7/ Origen.

Did you hear anything more of the tle Father Pita told us of the in-
troduction into the hacienda near Ferranafe by a man from Catacaos?
8/ Mortality.

You spoke of there “having been about 1,000 deaths” in the district
north-east of Ferranafe: Can you form any estimate of the number of
deaths in this 1921 epidemic?

You need be in no hurry to answer this. I judge that if you write
by Sept. 15th, I should get it in time. Also, you need not confine
yourself to the questions asked. Any information you have time to
give will be gratefully received by the Tropical Society. Also, if you
3
haven't time to write at all, don't do it. I don't want to impose
on you. You have enough to do. I have enough for a paper.

I suspect that you and the International Health Board have saved
Peru. One can't be sure until innext January. I think, however, that if
it, the infection, has not established itself in some place south of
Trujillo that you will have it eliminated by the end of the year--or
even by Oct. or Nov. 1st.: Although I won't feel entirely sure until the
end of the next hot season--June /22.

I did right to return to the U. S. I have been of more service to
you here--especially in the beginning--than if I had stayed. Yet I do
wish I could have gone back with, or in place of, White and stayed
with you as long as was necessary or until the end. However, there is
no decision involved and therefore I will not worry.
What of Wrightson?
div1.closer:
Very truly your friend, Address
Dr/ H. R. Carter,
2121 California St. N. W.
Washington, D. C.
